content.text: In our introduction to semantic elements , you learned to use the heading elements.
content.html: In our introduction to semantic elements, you learned to use the heading elements.

content.text: A heading is text that describes the content that follows it.
content.html: A heading is text that describes the content that follows it.

content.text: What you might not know, is that headings are important for accessible navigation. Sighted users scan a web page to understand the structure of the page. The same way, screen reader users use headings to navigate and scan the page.
content.html: What you might not know, is that headings are important for accessible navigation. Sighted users scan a web page to understand the structure of the page. The same way, screen reader users use headings to navigate and scan the page.

content.text: The headings must be clear, both visually and use clear wording. The heading structure of a page forms the outline of the page. You might think of this like the skeleton of the page.
content.html: The headings must be clear, both visually and use clear wording. The heading structure of a page forms the outline of the page. You might think of this like the skeleton of the page.

content.text: News papers use a lot of headings. The front page of The Straits Times has over 80 headings.
content.html: News papers use a lot of headings. The front page of The Straits Times has over 80 headings.

content.text: All these headings form an outline.
This is a good document outline. The levels make sense. The text is clear.
content.html: This is a good document outline. The levels make sense. The text is clear.

links.text: the importance of headings when using a screen reader

content.text: In the next module you will learn about assistive technologies and screen readers. As a teaser, you should watch Rob Dodson from Google demonstrate the importance of headings when using a screen reader . The first five minutes of the video explains the use of headings in a screen reader.
